title: Can regular guitar strings be put on a bass guitar? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not really, no. In a serious (“I’m out of strings and my last one broke or something) situation a improvised TEMPORARY replacement might work, but the only real similarity between a standard bass and guitar is they both have necks. A bass neck is several inches longer and regular guitar strings most likely won’t reach the tuning pegs, then there’s the intonation issue and the electronic fact that a thinner guitar string won’t impact the pickups in the same way. The bridge and nut are grooved for much thicker strings as well. BUT, never say never. When I was delegated as bass player in my 12–13 yr olds First Real Band, I had no idea there was a difference and all I had to go on was speciation and fuzzy Paul McCartney photos, so my Dad found a Kay 6 String electric ( a real “log”) and we removed two tuning pegs and made a makeshift 4 string nut and he bought me very heavy gauge guitar strings. I have little memory of how it actually sounded because I had no idea what a real bass was supposed to sound like! But there I was in our first group picture, thumping 1–5,1–5 to “Hang on Sloopy”… But if you don’t need to go thru all that, use bass strings…. Play on!

Normally I would say you couldn't do this as guitar strings would be too short and there might be issues with the (,lack of) string tension and the effect on the truss rod as well. However, I did once see someone playing a Fender Bass VI in a bar in Puerto Rico with a mixture of guitar and and bass strings. A bass VI is a 6 string short scale Bass (30″) tuned one octave below a guitar. If I recall correctly, the bottom 4 were the Bass strings and the top B and E were guitar strings so he could play the bass lines and add the odd guitar fill.

NO! They are different sizes and gauges. There are 5 string basses and 6 string basses now. Back when I learned to play bass guitar it only had 4 strings. If you're asking me for an opinion or endorsement, I would personally recommend GHS Boomers Medium Gauge. They cost a little more but they stay in tune well and I've played a lot of shows with them. Also, I usually only have to change strings once a year. Don't cut corners to save a few bucks. If you're going to play in front of people, you should try to give them the best product you can deliver. There is no substitute for quality!

I don’t think strings are long enough to reach the machine heads. If you had a medium, or student sized bass, I sure you can. The problem is, you will need to replace the nut, because your new strings are much thinner than the bass strings, and you will most likely experience buzz . It also won’t be as meaty as a bass string
Can you? Yes, you can. Would you want to? Absolutely not. It would be like putting go-cart tires on a monster truck.

Begs the question of “why?” A bass, as designed, actually makes a pretty lousy guitar. It would require all sorts of compromises and modifications to even make it playable. String scale, issues with nut and bridge using thinner strings, and what would be excessive width/length of the neck would make for uncomfortable playing for standard guitar techniques.
No. Guitar strings are not the same scale as bass guitar strings. They also would slip around on the bridge and in the nut slot. Get real and buy some bass strings.
Not in any useful way. Guitar strings are so thin that they would be too loose when tuned to the pitches of a bass guitar.
The short answer is no. The bass guitar strings are of different gauges compared to a 6 string guitar.
It would be meaningless to do so. Bass strings as you can see are designed to resonate the Bass sound.
